elements.title: Gain-Frame Price Architecture with Embedded Reference Comparison
elements.problem: The platform currently presents pricing information as standalone figures: '$80/night', '4-Week Rent: $960', 'Total: $3,840'. These numbers are meaningless in isolation because, as Kahneman demonstrates, all financial evaluations are relative to a reference point. Steve Zhang's reference is Sonder at $90/night. Without an explicit comparison, his System 1 performs a rough, error-prone comparison that systematically disadvantages Split Lease. Here is why: Sonder's $90/night is a complete, certain, all-inclusive price (cleaning, amenities, no setup). Split Lease's $80/night requires the guest to mentally add the value of leave-your-stuff, full kitchen, consistent space, and medium-term savings -- additions that System 1 does not perform automatically. The information architecture creates an asymmetry: Sonder's value is immediately legible, Split Lease's value requires System 2 computation. Kahneman's work on vivid outcomes shows that 'a rich and vivid representation of the outcome reduces the role of probability in the evaluation.' Sonder's price is vivid (one number, everything included). Split Lease's price is abstract (base rate + invisible structural advantages). The information architecture must reverse this asymmetry.
elements.solution: Restructure all price displays into a three-layer hierarchy that surfaces the reference comparison before the absolute price: LAYER 1 (Primary, largest type): The gain vs. reference. 'Save $120/month vs. Sonder' or 'Save $1,440/year vs. hotels.' This is the first thing the guest reads. It answers the only question that matters: 'Is this better than what I have now?' LAYER 2 (Secondary): The total monthly cost for the guest's specific pattern. '$960/month for 3 nights/week.' This answers: 'Can I afford this?' LAYER 3 (Tertiary, smallest type): The nightly rate and calculation breakdown. '$80/night x 12 nights/month = $960.' This answers: 'How is this calculated?' Additionally, a non-financial value strip below the price: three icons with labels showing structural advantages that have no dollar equivalent in the reference alternative: 'Leave your belongings' (icon: suitcase with checkmark), 'Same space every visit' (icon: home with repeat arrow), 'Full kitchen included' (icon: kitchen). These are vivid, imageable advantages that Kahneman's research shows will reduce the certainty premium the guest demands.

evidence.detail: Steve: 'I also say to Sonder quite a bit... in Boston, I can get it down to like 90 a month... I don't need a kitchen.' Steve is actively making tradeoffs against his reference. He has sacrificed kitchen access to reduce price. The information architecture must show him that Split Lease does not require this tradeoff: he gets a kitchen AND a lower total monthly cost.

Kahneman: 'Adding irrelevant but vivid details to a monetary outcome also disrupts calculation... the blue envelope evokes a richer and more fluent representation.' The non-financial value strip (leave belongings, same space, kitchen) adds vivid details to the monetary outcome. These details are not irrelevant -- they are real advantages -- but their vividness serves the same function: making the Split Lease outcome more imageable and therefore more compelling.

Kahneman: 'What is missing from the figure is an indication of the individual's current income and leisure... by failing to display it, the theorists invite you to believe that the reference point does not matter, but by now you know that of course it does.' The current Split Lease price display makes the same error: it shows the price without the reference point, inviting the guest to evaluate in a vacuum.

Igor explains the pricing advantage to Steve through direct comparison: 'If you can resegment the market from sort of the average hotel guest to average monthly as your cost basis, then it is pennies on the dollar for the supply.' The conversational comparison is effective because it provides the reference (hotel nightly rate) before the value (Split Lease monthly rate). The information architecture must replicate this sequence.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Reference comparison > Monthly total > Nightly rate. The guest's first processing is 'Is this better than what I have?' not 'What does this cost?' The hierarchy must match the cognitive sequence, not the data model.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Progressive comparison disclosure: the gain is shown first (Layer 1), the total cost is shown on click or scroll (Layer 2), and the calculation breakdown is available on demand (Layer 3). This matches the guest's decision depth: casual browsers need only Layer 1, serious evaluators need Layers 1+2, analytical guests like Steve need all three.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Layer 1 must be parseable in under 2 seconds (one short sentence and a number). Layer 2 adds one additional number. Layer 3 is optional and expandable. The non-financial value strip uses icons with 2-3 word labels -- no sentences.
elements.scan_order: Top: Gain statement (green, prominent). Middle: Monthly total + nights-per-week. Bottom: Rate breakdown (expandable). Below: Non-financial value strip (horizontal icon row).
exclude: Do NOT show cleaning fees, service fees, or taxes as separate line items in Layers 1-2. These create loss signals. If there are fees, include them in the total and note 'All fees included' as a trust signal.
Do NOT show the nightly rate as the primary price on listing cards. Nightly rate invites direct comparison to Sonder/Airbnb nightly rates, where the structural advantage is invisible.
Do NOT use percentage savings as the primary gain statement. '$120/month saved' is concrete. '13% cheaper' is abstract and requires the guest to compute the base.

elements.title: Counter-Offer Information Hierarchy: Preserved Terms First, Changed Terms Second
elements.problem: When a host counters a guest's proposal, the information architecture of the counter-offer display determines whether the guest perceives the negotiation as collaborative (moving toward agreement) or adversarial (losing proposed terms). Kahneman's research on loss aversion in negotiations shows that 'the concessions you make to me are my gains, but they are your losses; they cause you much more pain than they give me pleasure.' The current journey map shows counter-offers by navigating to a 'Proposal Detail Page' that shows 'the Guest's submitted terms' and the host's changes. If the first information the guest processes is 'your duration was reduced from 16 weeks to 10 weeks,' their System 1 codes a 6-week loss before System 2 can contextualize it. Steve Zhang's analytical nature will amplify this: he will immediately calculate the financial impact of the loss ($80/night x 18 nights x 6 weeks = $8,640 of 'lost' value) before considering whether 10 weeks is actually a good outcome. The information architecture must present what was PRESERVED before what was CHANGED, and what was CHANGED must be framed as a feature, not a deficit.
elements.solution: Restructure the counter-offer display into three distinct information zones presented in strict order: ZONE 1 -- PRESERVED (70% of visual weight): 'The host agreed to these terms:' followed by all unchanged elements with green checkmarks. Nightly rate: $80 (checkmark). Move-in date: March 1 (checkmark). Lease style: Nights-of-the-week (checkmark). Days: Tue-Wed-Thu (checkmark). This zone should be visually dominant -- large type, green accents, checkmarks. It anchors the guest in what they have gained from the pre-proposal state (nothing) to the current state (agreement on multiple terms). ZONE 2 -- ADJUSTED (25% of visual weight): 'The host suggests this adjustment:' followed by the changed term(s) with a neutral icon (not red, not crossed-out). Duration: 10 weeks (host suggested) vs. your proposal of 16 weeks. Below: 'This reduces your total commitment from $3,840 to $2,400 -- a $1,440 smaller commitment.' Frame the change as a reduction in commitment (a gain in flexibility) rather than a loss of duration. ZONE 3 -- ACTION (5% of visual weight): Two buttons: 'Accept and Secure Your Space' (primary, prominent) and 'Suggest Different Terms' (secondary, subdued). The 'Accept' button uses the certainty-effect language: 'Secure' implies converting uncertain negotiation into certain outcome.

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Defending the Status Quo section
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'Many of the messages that negotiators exchange are attempts to communicate a reference point and provide an anchor to the other side.' The counter-offer display IS the platform's attempt to set the guest's reference point. If the reference is set at 'what you preserved' (multiple agreed terms), the change feels small. If set at 'what you proposed' (the original terms), the change feels like a loss.

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Defending the Status Quo section
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'Negotiations over a shrinking pie are especially difficult... People tend to be much more easygoing when they bargain over an expanding pie.' Zone 1 (Preserved) establishes that the pie is expanding: the guest has gone from 'no agreement on anything' to 'agreement on 4 out of 5 terms.' The one adjusted term is a small residual, not a major loss.

Igor: 'They have a sense of schedule certainty in a sense of schedule uncertainty.' The counter-offer display must maximize the certainty signal (4 terms agreed) and minimize the uncertainty signal (1 term adjusted). The 4:1 ratio of certain-to-uncertain information creates the psychological sense of near-resolution.

Kahneman demonstrates that the step from 'almost certain' to 'certain' is psychologically enormous. The 'Accept and Secure' button converts the negotiation from 'almost agreed' to 'agreed.' This is the certainty effect applied to negotiation closure.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Preserved > Adjusted > Action. The guest processes agreement before disagreement, gains before losses, certainty before uncertainty. This order is non-negotiable because System 1 processes information in presentation order and the first impression shapes the evaluation of everything that follows.
elements.disclosure_pattern: All-at-once with visual hierarchy. Unlike progressive disclosure (where information is hidden until requested), the counter-offer should show everything immediately -- but the VISUAL WEIGHT determines processing order. Zone 1 is large, green, prominent. Zone 2 is smaller, neutral-colored. Zone 3 is a simple button row.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Zone 1 should contain no more than 5 preserved terms (anything more creates a list-scanning burden). Zone 2 should contain exactly 1 changed term (if the host changed multiple terms, they should be bundled into a single narrative: 'The host adjusted your duration and start date'). Zone 3 is two buttons maximum.
elements.scan_order: Top: 'The host agreed to these terms' heading. Below: checkmarked list of preserved terms. Middle: 'The host suggests this adjustment' heading. Below: one adjusted term with reframed narrative. Bottom: Accept/Counter buttons.
exclude: Do NOT show a side-by-side diff of original proposal vs. counter. Diffs are loss-highlighting tools. The display must be a single, forward-looking offer with context.
Do NOT use red, orange, or warning colors for adjusted terms. Use neutral purple or gray. Red triggers System 1 threat detection.
Do NOT show the financial 'loss' of the change without also showing the financial 'gain' (reduced commitment). If duration went down, total cost also went down -- show both.
Do NOT auto-calculate 'You lose $X of value' or similar loss-framed summaries. If the platform must show the delta, frame it as 'Your commitment is reduced by $X.'

elements.title: Certainty Timeline at Every Post-Commitment Transition
elements.problem: After a guest commits (proposal submission, counter-offer acceptance, move-in preparation), they enter a waiting state where the platform has their commitment but has not yet delivered the outcome. This is the most psychologically dangerous zone in the journey. Kahneman's certainty effect shows that the gap between 'almost certain' (95%) and 'certain' (100%) is where the most anxiety lives. A guest who has accepted terms but has not received documents is at 95% certainty. A guest who has received documents but has not moved in is at 97%. Each percentage point toward 100% matters disproportionately. Steve Zhang's experience with Sonder's annoying text support (0:35:39) shows that even sophisticated users are sensitive to communication failures during active commitments. The current journey map shows that 'documents are sent' after acceptance, but the guest has no visibility into the timeline. When will documents arrive? When is payment processed? When will the host send check-in instructions? Each unanswered question is a certainty gap that the guest's System 1 fills with worst-case scenarios (Kahneman: 'the mere reminder of a bad event is treated in System 1 as threatening').
elements.solution: At every post-commitment transition, display a Certainty Timeline -- a visual sequence of upcoming events with specific timeframes and status indicators. The timeline transforms the abstract future into a concrete sequence, converting uncertainty into certainty step-by-step. ACCEPTANCE TIMELINE: Step 1: 'Lease documents generated' -- within 2 hours (shows timer or status: 'In progress' / 'Complete'). Step 2: 'Documents sent for review and signature' -- within 24 hours. Step 3: 'Payment authorization confirmed' -- upon signature. Step 4: 'Move-in instructions sent by host' -- 72 hours before move-in. Step 5: 'Your space is ready' -- on move-in date. Each step should have three states: upcoming (gray), in progress (purple pulse), complete (green checkmark). The timeline should be visible on the Leases page as a persistent widget, not just in a one-time email. PRE-MOVE-IN TIMELINE: Condenses to the logistical steps. 'Check-in instructions received' (checkmark or pending). 'House Manual available' (checkmark or pending). 'Host contact confirmed' (checkmark). 'Parking instructions' (checkmark). ACTIVE LEASE TIMELINE: Shifts to recurring events. 'Next stay: Tue Mar 5 -- Thu Mar 7.' 'Next payment: Mar 15, $960.' 'Lease ends: Jun 1 (renewal available May 1).' The Certainty Timeline is the guest's anti-anxiety tool. Every checkmark is a micro-certainty delivery that moves them from 95% toward 100%.

evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'A 2% risk of not winning the prize reduces the utility of the gamble by 13%, from 100 to 87.1.' Each unresolved post-commitment step is a small risk that feels much larger than its probability. The Certainty Timeline resolves these risks one by one, and each resolution delivers a disproportionate psychological reward.

Kahneman: 'When an unlikely event becomes the focus of attention, we will assign it much more weight than its probability deserves.' During the waiting period after acceptance, rare-but-dramatic failure scenarios (documents never arrive, host cancels, payment charged incorrectly) become the focus of attention. The Certainty Timeline keeps attention on the expected positive sequence rather than the unlikely negative ones.

Steve on Sonder: 'Their text conversations are, if you don't respond within like 30 seconds, you're like, who does this?' Steve is sensitized to communication gaps. The Certainty Timeline eliminates communication gaps by making progress visible without requiring the guest to ask.

Steve: 'I came back because I thought I have to go back to January, but that's not going to happen.' He has been burned by uncertain timelines. The Certainty Timeline is the antidote: explicit, specific, updated in real time.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Completed steps > Current step > Future steps. The guest should see their progress (certainty already delivered) before their current position (certainty in progress) before the remaining steps (certainty forthcoming). This creates a forward-momentum feeling.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Always-visible timeline with expandable detail. The main timeline shows step labels and status icons (5-7 items). Clicking a step reveals detail (e.g., clicking 'Documents sent' reveals the document list and signature link). The guest should never need to navigate away from the Leases page to understand their status.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 7 timeline steps visible at once (Miller's law). Each step label is 3-5 words maximum. Status is communicated through color/icon, not text. Expanded detail should not exceed one paragraph.
elements.scan_order: Left-to-right or top-to-bottom chronological sequence. Completed steps recede visually (smaller, grayed). Current step is highlighted (purple, bold). Future steps are visible but subdued.
exclude: Do NOT hide the timeline in an email-only format. Emails get lost, archived, or filtered. The timeline must live on the platform where the guest returns to check status.
Do NOT show estimated times as ranges ('1-3 business days'). Ranges are uncertainty. Show a specific target ('by March 2') and update if delayed.
Do NOT use passive language ('Documents will be sent'). Use active language with accountability ('We are generating your documents' or 'Your host is preparing check-in instructions').
Do NOT let timeline steps stay in 'pending' state without explanation. If a step is delayed, show why and what the guest can do.

elements.title: Loss-Prevention Information Display on the Active Lease Dashboard
elements.problem: During the active lease, the guest's reference point is their initial experience: the space quality, the cost, the host responsiveness, the ease of date management. Kahneman's negativity dominance principle shows that 'bad emotions, bad parents, and bad feedback have more impact than good ones.' A single unexpected charge, a single unresponsive host message, or a single confusing date-change process can create a loss that requires 5 positive interactions to offset (Gottman's 5:1 ratio). The Leases page is the guest's primary recurring touchpoint -- they visit it weekly to check schedules, payments, and stay details. The current Leases page shows basic information (active leases, payment history, stay calendar) but does not proactively surface loss-prevention information. It waits for the guest to discover problems rather than intercepting them. For an analytical guest like Steve Zhang, who will track ROI continuously and who is already sensitized to operational friction from Sonder, the Leases page must function as a loss-prevention dashboard that maintains the guest's positive reference point.
elements.solution: Redesign the active lease section of the Leases page as a loss-prevention information architecture with four panels: PANEL 1 -- SAVINGS TRACKER (top, most prominent): 'You have saved $X vs. [reference alternative] over [duration].' This running total reinforces the gain frame and counteracts the natural tendency to forget savings over time. Below: a mini-chart showing monthly savings trend. This panel keeps the guest in the gains domain, making small negative events (a late host message, a minor scheduling friction) less impactful because the overall frame is positive. PANEL 2 -- UPCOMING EVENTS (middle-left): Next 3 stays with dates and any pending confirmations. Next payment with amount and date. Any pending date-change requests. This is the certainty panel: everything the guest needs to know about the immediate future. No ambiguity. PANEL 3 -- HOST STATUS (middle-right): Host response time (average and recent). Last message from host. Host rating. This panel gives the guest visibility into the relationship health metric. If host responsiveness degrades, the guest sees it early and the platform can intervene before the guest codes it as a loss. PANEL 4 -- LEASE HEALTH (bottom): Lease progress bar (e.g., 'Week 7 of 10'). Renewal status ('Renewal available starting May 1'). Any action items (cleaning photos to submit, reviews to write). This panel provides the macro-certainty: where am I in the lifecycle and what is coming next?

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Bad Events / Negativity Dominance section
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'The self is more motivated to avoid bad self-definitions than to pursue good ones. Bad impressions and bad stereotypes are quicker to form and more resistant to disconfirmation than good ones.' The savings tracker (Panel 1) creates a strong positive self-definition ('I am saving money by using Split Lease') that buffers against bad impressions from minor negative events.

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Loss Aversion in the Law section
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'People who learned from a new catalog that the merchant was now charging less for a product that they had recently bought at a higher price reduced their future purchases from that supplier by 15%.' If the guest discovers a payment discrepancy on their own, it is a loss. If the platform proactively explains any charge variance, it is transparency. Panel 2 (Upcoming Events) prevents self-discovered losses by making all financial events visible in advance.

Steve on Sonder friction: 'Their text conversations are, if you don't respond within like 30 seconds... It's super annoying.' Panel 3 (Host Status) directly addresses this by making host responsiveness visible. If Steve's host is responsive, he sees the data and feels secure. If responsiveness drops, the platform intervenes before Steve's experience degrades.

Steve: 'Every time you have to set it up, your ROI is like a couple of days.' Steve thinks in ROI. Panel 1 (Savings Tracker) speaks directly to his mental model by quantifying the ongoing ROI of his Split Lease choice.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Gains (savings) > Certainty (upcoming events) > Relationship (host status) > Lifecycle (lease health). The guest's first processing should be positive-frame reinforcement, followed by near-term certainty, then relationship health, then lifecycle context.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Dashboard with all four panels visible simultaneously. No progressive disclosure for the primary view -- the guest should see the complete picture on landing. Each panel has expandable detail (click savings tracker for monthly breakdown, click upcoming events for full calendar, etc.).
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Each panel has ONE headline number or status. Panel 1: '$720 saved so far.' Panel 2: 'Next stay: Tue Mar 5.' Panel 3: 'Host responds in ~2 hours.' Panel 4: 'Week 7 of 10.' Detail is available but not required for the primary scan.
elements.scan_order: Top: Savings tracker (positive frame). Middle-left: Upcoming events (certainty). Middle-right: Host status (relationship). Bottom: Lease health (lifecycle). Z-pattern scan for Western readers.
exclude: Do NOT show payment history as a list of debits. Debits are losses. Show payments as 'Investments in your space' with the savings comparison attached.
Do NOT show host rating if it degrades. Instead, show a 'We are working with your host to improve response time' message. Exposing degradation to the guest is showing them a loss.
Do NOT show lease progress as a countdown ('3 weeks remaining'). Countdowns are loss-coded (losing remaining time). Show as achievement: 'Week 7 of 10 completed.'
Do NOT clutter the dashboard with promotional content (upgrade offers, referral programs). These are distractions that reduce the loss-prevention effectiveness.

elements.title: Rare-Event Defusal Through Preemptive Risk Acknowledgment
elements.problem: Kahneman's chapter on rare events reveals a paradox: people either completely ignore rare events or massively overweight them, depending on whether the event is brought to their attention. For a guest evaluating a Split Lease listing, the rare-but-dramatic negative scenarios (scam listing, terrible host, space does not match photos, host cancels day before move-in) are precisely the kind of vivid, emotional events that System 1 overweights when they come to mind. The paradox for the platform is: if the listing page does not address these fears, the guest's System 1 may never think of them (good), or may generate them spontaneously and overweight them massively (catastrophic). Steve Zhang is especially relevant here because he is sophisticated enough to imagine failure modes and analytical enough to demand evidence of their mitigation. He mentions Sonder's annoying support -- but he still uses Sonder, partly because it is a known brand with an implicit safety guarantee. Split Lease, as a marketplace connecting strangers, does not have this implicit safety. The information architecture must defuse rare-event fears without activating them.
elements.solution: Implement a preemptive risk acknowledgment system that addresses the top 3-4 guest fears BEFORE the guest's System 1 generates them, using a technique that Kahneman's research supports: making the feared event and its mitigation equally vivid, so the mitigation receives the same overweighting as the threat. This means: (1) On the listing detail page, include a 'Your Protection' section positioned AFTER the photo gallery and BEFORE the proposal button. This section uses a 'shield' visual metaphor and addresses fears in this order: 'Verified Host' (host has been vetted, ID confirmed, background check complete -- with a specific badge). 'Accurate Photos' (photos verified within last X days, or host provides a recent photo/video tour). 'Payment Protected' (your payment is held in escrow until 24 hours after check-in -- if the space does not match the listing, full refund). 'Cancellation Coverage' (if the host cancels, we find you an equivalent space or refund 100% + X% inconvenience credit). (2) The critical information architecture principle: each protection statement must be EQUALLY VIVID as the fear it defuses. Kahneman shows that 'a rich and vivid representation of the outcome reduces the role of probability in the evaluation.' If the fear is vivid (arriving to find a scam listing) and the protection is abstract ('we have a refund policy'), the fear wins. The protection must be equally concrete: 'Your payment is held in escrow. If the space does not match, you upload a photo of the discrepancy and receive your refund within 24 hours.' (3) DO NOT use a traditional FAQ format. FAQs require the guest to self-diagnose their fear and search for the answer. The preemptive format addresses fears the guest has not yet articulated, which Kahneman's research on the possibility effect supports: 'Reducing or mitigating the risk is not adequate; to eliminate the worry the probability must be brought down to zero.' The information must convey zero-risk, not reduced-risk.

evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'When an unlikely event becomes the focus of attention, we will assign it much more weight than its probability deserves... Reducing or mitigating the risk is not adequate; to eliminate the worry the probability must be brought down to zero.' The protection statements must convey elimination of risk, not reduction. 'Full refund' and 'replacement space' are zero-risk language.

Kahneman: 'Terrorism works... it induces an availability cascade. An extremely vivid image of death and damage, constantly reinforced by media attention and frequent conversations, becomes highly accessible.' The guest equivalent of terrorism is the 'Airbnb horror story' -- widely shared, vivid, and available. The platform cannot prevent the guest from having encountered these stories. It can only make its protection equally available and vivid.

Steve on Sonder: mentions operational friction but continues using the service. This reveals that Steve has made a risk assessment: Sonder's brand provides implicit protection that compensates for its friction. Split Lease must provide explicit protection that is at least as strong as Sonder's implicit protection.

Igor: 'I put my space up on Airbnb and it was just like, oh, like a light bulb. Like people willing to pay me nearly $400 a night.' The Airbnb reference is omnipresent. Every guest brings Airbnb's mixed reputation (great concept, horror stories) as mental baggage. The preemptive risk section must differentiate Split Lease's protections from Airbnb's.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Protection > Features > Price details. On the listing detail page, the guest's System 1 is running a threat assessment concurrently with the value assessment. The protection section must resolve the threat assessment before the guest reaches the proposal button, or the unresolved threat will suppress conversion.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Always visible, not hidden behind a 'Learn more' link. The 4 protection items should be displayed as compact cards (icon + one-sentence statement) that can be expanded for detail. The compact format signals 'we have this covered' without requiring reading. The expanded detail provides the evidence for analytical guests like Steve.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: 4 protection items maximum. Each compact card: one icon + one sentence (under 15 words). Expanded detail: one paragraph maximum. The section should occupy no more than 1/6 of the listing detail page vertical space.
elements.scan_order: Shield icon and 'Your Protection' heading first. Then 4 horizontal cards: Verified Host | Accurate Photos | Payment Protected | Cancellation Coverage. Each card is scannable in 2 seconds.
exclude: Do NOT use legal language in the compact view. 'Subject to our terms and conditions' triggers System 1 suspicion. Use plain language: 'Full refund if the space does not match.'
Do NOT list every possible risk scenario. This activates fears the guest did not have. Address only the top 3-4 universal fears.
Do NOT position the protection section after the proposal button. By the time the guest reaches the button, they need the threat assessment resolved.
Do NOT compare Split Lease's protections to competitors. 'Unlike Airbnb, we...' invites the guest to think about Airbnb horror stories. Simply state what Split Lease does.
